content.text: Bruxism is the involuntary grinding, gnashing, or clenching of teeth. Sleep bruxism occurs during sleep and is classified as a sleep-related movement disorder.
It affects approximately 8-31% of the general population, with higher rates in children. Most people are unaware they grind their teeth until a partner notices or a dentist spots wear patterns.

items: Teeth grinding or clenching loud enough to wake your partner
Teeth that are flattened, fractured, chipped, or loose
Worn tooth enamel exposing deeper layers
Tired or tight jaw muscles, especially upon waking
Jaw, neck, or face pain or soreness
Dull headache starting at the temples
Sleep disruption for you or your partner

content.text: The exact cause of bruxism isn't fully understood, but research has identified several risk factors:

items: Stress, anxiety, or tension (most common trigger)
Sleep disorders like obstructive sleep apnea
Lifestyle factors: caffeine (~1.5x odds), alcohol (~2x odds), smoking (>2x odds)
Certain medications, especially SSRIs (responsible for ~74% of reported antidepressant-induced bruxism cases)
GERD (acid reflux) - associated in case-control studies

content.text: No single intervention cures bruxism, but a strategic combination of evidence-based approaches can effectively manage symptoms:

items.name: Night Guards
items.description: Custom-fitted hard acrylic splints protect teeth from damage. Per the 2007 Cochrane review (most recent available), they don't reduce grinding but prevent costly dental repairs.

items.name: Biofeedback
items.description: Real-time monitoring with gentle alerts may reduce clenching in the short term, though effects can diminish over time.

items.name: Lifestyle Changes
items.description: Reducing caffeine, alcohol, and improving sleep hygiene. Zero cost with documented risk reduction.

items.name: Stress Management
items.description: Meditation, deep breathing, exercise. Addresses a major trigger for bruxism.

items.name: Medication Review
items.description: If bruxism started after beginning an SSRI, discuss with your doctor (never stop abruptly). Buspirone may help after 2-3 weeks.

items.name: Botox (Severe Cases)
items.description: Effective for pain and force reduction, but expensive and requires ongoing treatment.

content.text: OpenJaw uses EMG (electromyography) monitoring through a Muse headband to detect jaw muscle activity during sleep.
When clenching is detected, your Apple Watch delivers a gentle haptic vibration to interrupt the grinding pattern without fully waking you.

Small studies suggest biofeedback may reduce EMG activity in the short term, though a 2018 systematic review notes that long-term evidence is limited and habituation can occur after several weeks of use.

Beyond real-time biofeedback, OpenJaw provides a central place to track all your bruxism management habits, monitor your progress over time, and access evidence-based information to help you take control of your treatment.
